column2: Client A: Because the property had achieved planning permission after the purchase price was agreed, lender was able to lend against enhanced planning uplift value, which enabled them to extend to 90% net LtPP. Client was seeking a 12m term but lender insisted on a 6m additional sale period – term became 18m

Client B: Was seeking a 2nd charge regulated bridge. Therefore LTV incorporates both his existing 1st charge and target 2nd charge. Loan-to-purchase price (LtPP) was irrelevant because the client already owned the asset. Client was indifferent between rolled or retained interest

Client C: Client was seeking a 2y term but ended up fuzzy matching the lender whose maximum term was 12m. Client accepted this as the interest rate was much cheaper than the other solutions. The cost of refinancing a 12m term again in 12m was cheaper than the bridging alternative, therefore the client fuzzy matched the lender. Sometimes term will require an exact match for the client (is a deal breaker). There are instances too where the lender will fuzzy match the client, such as going lower than their minimum loan size to win the business
